qas.question: Who obtained a large block of the Cub's shares in 1914?
Who assumed majority ownership of the Cubs franchise by the 1916 season?
Who did Albert Lasker bring in to be his partner of the Chicago Cubs?
Where did the Cubs move to after leaving the West Side Grounds?

context: In 1914, advertising executive <a0_0><a1_0>Albert Lasker<a1_0/><a0_0/> obtained a large block of the club's shares and before the 1916 season assumed majority ownership of the franchise. Lasker brought in a wealthy partner, <a2_0>Charles Weeghman<a2_0/>, the proprietor of a popular chain of lunch counters who had previously owned the Chicago Whales of the short-lived Federal League. As principal owners, the pair moved the club from the West Side Grounds to the much newer <a3_0>Weeghman Park<a3_0/>, which had been constructed for the Whales only two years earlier, where they remain to this day. The Cubs responded by winning a pennant in the war-shortened season of 1918, where they played a part in another team's curse: the Boston Red Sox defeated Grover Cleveland Alexander's Cubs four games to two in the 1918 World Series, Boston's last Series championship until 2004.
